physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with silver screw cap
proxyLocation: slightly above center of the white table
utilizationMethod: Grip the narrow neck (≈3 cm diameter) of the bottle as you would the wooden handle of the virtual mug. Keep the main body filled with water so it feels bottom-heavy. Tilt the bottle toward your face while maintaining the power-grip; the liquid’s inertia will lag slightly, creating a convincing downward moment similar to a full wooden tankard.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate weight that feels substantial since it's full. The weight distribution should feel bottom-heavy.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user will perform a cylindrical power-grip around the vertical wooden handle (≈2 cm diameter). Fingers curl fully around the rod while the thumb opposes on the far side, similar to holding a thick marker. Once secured, the forearm is raised and the wrist supinates to bring the lip of the mug toward the mouth. The elbow flexes and the shoulder raises for sipping motions, followed by gentle wrist pronation to set the mug back down. Because the mug is bottom-heavy (liquid plus a metal-banded base), the user will feel a noticeable downward moment when the mug is tilted; they must counterbalance with wrist torque. During manipulation the mug itself remains rigid, giving no deformation feedback—only the shift of liquid weight that creates a slight lag on direction changes. No finger repositioning is expected once the grip is established; interaction is dominated by forearm and wrist articulation.

physicalObject: white paper towel roll
proxyLocation: top right of the white table
utilizationMethod: Hook your thumb inside the cardboard core and wrap your fingers around the outer paper surface, forming a curved power-grip about the tube. The roll’s diameter gives a handle-like rod, and its modest weight provides a sense of mass when you pronate/supinate the wrist to imitate sipping.

physicalObject: red and white beverage carton with screw cap
proxyLocation: right side of the white table
utilizationMethod: Hold the top corner of the carton like a vertical handle—thumb on one panel, fingers on the opposite panel. Fill the carton with liquid to create a bottom-heavy feel, then raise and tilt it as though drinking from a mug. The rectangular body substitutes for the wooden barrel while the corner edge mimics a slender handle.

physicalObject: transparent disposable plastic cup
proxyLocation: just left of the water bottle, above center of the white table
utilizationMethod: Insert your index finger inside the cup and curl the remaining fingers around the outer wall, treating the rim as a thin curved rod. Even though it is lighter, the finger-through-rim grip trains the same wrist articulation used to lift and tip a handled mug.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with silver screw cap
proxyLocation: slightly above the center of the white table
utilizationMethod: Grip the lower third of the bottle so that the capped end projects forward. Because most of the water mass is now forward of the hand, the bottle feels head-heavy, giving a convincing sense of an axe head that lags and then pulls through the swing. The cylindrical body lets the user close fingers fully in a power-grasp, closely matching the axe handle.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user secures a firm saber-style power grip around the lower portion of the wooden handle, thumb and fingers wrapping fully to stabilize against rotational torque. Primary motions are broad shoulder-driven swings with elbow extension, producing an arcing trajectory that brings the heavy metal head downward or sideways toward a target. The head-heavy inertia causes the tool to lag slightly behind hand motion on initiation and to continue forward after the hand begins decelerating, so the user feels the need to brace and absorb recoil on impact. Fine orientation adjustments (edge alignment) are made through wrist pronation/supination, but most force is generated through gross arm motion. The axe stays rigid; the only feedback change is inertial, not shape or compliance.

physicalObject: white paper towel roll
proxyLocation: top-right of the white table
utilizationMethod: Hold the roll near one edge so that a long length extends outward. Although light, the roll’s diameter supports a full fist grasp and its bulk provides some swing inertia. Users can practice the broad arcing motion and wrist alignment without danger of impact.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with silver screw cap
proxyLocation: standing upright near the center of the white table
utilizationMethod: Grip the bottle just above its lower third so that most of the mass (the full metal body and any remaining liquid) sits forward of your hand, creating a head-heavy feel. Swing downward in short arcs, letting the weight pull your wrist much like a real hammer head while your closed fingers feel the cylindrical circumference of the bottle as the handle.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user employs a carpentry-style power grip a bit above the handle’s end, wrapping all fingers and the thumb around the cylindrical shaft. Striking actions involve short, controlled elbow flexion/extension combined with wrist snap to accelerate the head downward onto a virtual surface. The pronounced head-heavy mass creates a pendulum effect: once the swing starts, the user feels momentum pulling the handle forward, and upon impact must absorb rebound through wrist stiffness and slight elbow give. The hammer remains completely rigid; the response is felt only as sudden deceleration and possible vibration cues at the moment of contact.

physicalObject: white paper towel roll
proxyLocation: top-right area of the white table, leaning against itself
utilizationMethod: Hold the roll near one end so the remaining length becomes a foam-core ‘head’. Although light, its larger diameter at the striking end contrasts with the narrow grip, letting the user rehearse the hammer motion and grip geometry safely when forceful impact is not required.

proxyLocation: just left of the water bottle on the white table
utilizationMethod: Invert the cup and insert your fingers into the interior as though holding a short stubby handle; the flared rim acts as the lightweight head. You can practice quick wrist snaps and feel the sudden air resistance on impact, emulating the deceleration cue—even though mass is minimal.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user employs a carpentry-style power grip a bit above the handle’s end, wrapping all fingers and the thumb around the cylindrical shaft. Striking actions involve short, controlled elbow flexion/extension combined with wrist snap to accelerate the head downward onto a virtual surface. The pronounced head-heavy mass creates a pendulum effect: once the swing starts, the user feels momentum pulling the handle forward, and upon impact must absorb rebound through wrist stiffness and slight elbow give. The hammer remains completely rigid; the response is felt only as sudden deceleration and possible vibration cues at the moment of contact.

physicalObject: black stainless steel water bottle with silver screw cap
proxyLocation: slightly above the center of the white table
utilizationMethod: Grasp the lower half of the bottle in a pistol-style power grip, letting the heavier, cap-end extend forward to imitate the sickle’s forward-weighted blade. Sweep the bottle in compact, wrist-led arcs and then pull it toward the body; the bottle’s weight distribution gives moderate inertia that resembles the tool’s cutting pull.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user adopts a pistol-like power grip around the short handle, with the index finger often extended along the handle for directional control while the remaining fingers wrap underneath. Cutting motions are compact sweeping arcs generated by wrist ulnar deviation and forearm rotation, allowing the curved blade to hook around vegetation. After hooking, the user pulls the tool toward the body with elbow flexion to slice through the target. Moderate forward-weighted inertia means the curved blade feels present but not as concentrated as a hammer or axe head; it provides steady guidance during the pull without excessive overshoot. The tool stays rigid; feedback comes from continuous resistance during the pulling slice rather than a single impact.
